Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat with my family lighting up with messages about the holiday dinner. Mom’s text was clear: “It means a lot if you’re there. We haven’t all been together in months.” I could almost hear her voice, warm but insistent, and I knew how much she wanted me to be present, to laugh and share stories at the table. But then my phone buzzed again—this time, a message from Alex. “Can’t wait for our night together. I’ve missed you.” We’d both been so busy, and this was our only free evening before I left for a week. He was counting on me, hoping for a quiet night, just us. My chest tightened as I pictured disappointing either side. I wanted to be the sister who showed up, the girlfriend who cared. But I couldn’t be in two places at once. The weight of their expectations pressed on me, and I sat frozen, torn between the people I loved, wishing I didn’t have to choose.
